Tricia Miller (Former Prison Sister, Deceased) | spouse = | significantother = [[Lorna Morello]] (complicated) | children = | relatives = | religion = | nationality = [[United States|American]] | lbl21 = | data21 = | lbl22 = | data22 = | lbl23 = | data23 = | extra-hdr = | lbl31 = | data31 = | lbl32 = | data32 = | lbl33 = | data33 = }} '''Nicole Nichols''' is a fictional character played by [[Natasha Lyonne]] on the [[Netflix]] series ''[[Orange Is the New Black]]''. She is a recurring character in season one and a main character from season two onwards. Lyonne received an [[Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Guest Actress in a Comedy Series|Emmy nomination]] in 2014 for the role. ==Casting and background== Natasha Lyonne had intended to audition for the part of [[Lorna Morello]] but, according to Lyonne, "they wouldn’t let me [audition for Morello], because they already liked me for Nicky."{{cite news|url=http://www.ew.com/article/2014/06/23/orange-is-the-new-black-interviews|title=27 things we learned at the ''Orange Is the New Black'' press day|last=Busis|first=Hillary|date=June 23, 2014|work=[[Entertainment Weekly]]|accessdate=August 30, 2015}} [[Yael Stone]], who had auditioned for the role of Nichols, was cast as Morello. Lyonne feels that she can relate closely to Nichols's storyline as she has had experience of drug addiction. She says, "believe me, there's no shortage of things for me to draw on when it comes to Nicky's backstory".{{cite news|url=http://www.people.com/article/natasha-lyonne-orange-is-the-new-black-interview-emmy-nomination-season-3-spoilers|title=''OITNB''′s Natasha Lyonne Talks Emmys Jitters and Season 3 Spoilers: 'So Much Bloodshed'|last=Rayford Rubenstein|first=Janine|date=July 31, 2014|work=[[People (magazine)|People]]|accessdate=August 30, 2015}} The scar that is visible on Nichols's chest during the series is a real scar from Lyonne's heart surgery in 2012.{{cite news|url=https://www.buzzfeed.com/lyapalater/surprising-facts-about-orange-is-the-new-black#.hcPGoAM41|title=23 Surprising Facts About ''Orange Is The New Black''|last=Yapalater|first=Lauren|date=July 30, 2013|work=[[BuzzFeed]]|accessdate=August 30, 2015}} ''Orange Is the New Black'' is Lyonne's first time as a series regular.{{cite news|url=http://www.interviewmagazine.com/film/natasha-lyonne/|title=Natasha Lyonne, Locked Up|last=Brown|first=Emma|work=[[Interview (magazine)|Interview]]|accessdate=August 30, 2015}} ==Storylines== ===Season 1=== Nichols is first seen in the premier episode.{{cite news|url=http://www.vulture.com/2013/07/orange-is-the-new-black-episode-one-recap.html|title=''Orange Is the New Black'' Episode One Recap: A Nice White Lady|last=Henderson|first=Danielle|date=July 19, 2013|work=[[New York (magazine)|Vulture]]|accessdate=August 31, 2015}} Early on, she becomes friends with the series' protagonist [[Piper Chapman]] (played by [[Taylor Schilling]]). Nichols has a sexual relationship with Lorna Morello which ends in the fifth episode because Morello says that she wants to remain loyal to her fiancé and complains that Nichols is "making her feel like a cave".{{cite news|url=http://www.vulture.com/2013/08/orange-is-the-new-black-recap-season-1-chicken.html|title=''Orange Is the New Black'' Episode Five Recap: Definitely a Chicken|last=Henderson|first=Danielle|date=August 2, 2013|work=Vulture|accessdate=August 31, 2015}} [[List_of_Orange_Is_the_New_Black_characters#Galina_.22Red.22_Reznikov|Galina "Red" Reznikov]] (played by [[Kate Mulgrew]]) is a close friend and 'mother figure' to Nichols, however, the two have a disagreement when Red cuts off fellow inmate Tricia Miller (played by [[Madeline Brewer]]) and allows her to be sent to [[solitary confinement]].{{cite news|url=http://www.afterellen.com/tv/190938-orange-is-the-new-black-recap-1-8-moscow-mule|title=''Orange Is the New Black'' recap (1.8): Moscow Mule|last=Davis|first=Ali|date=July 18, 2013|work=[[AfterEllen.com and TheBacklot.com|After Ellen]]|accessdate=August 31, 2015}} Nichols retaliates against Red by reporting to a correctional officer exactly how Red manages to smuggle contraband into the prison.{{cite news|url=http://www.vulture.com/2013/08/orange-is-the-new-black-recap-season-1-episode-8-moscow-mule.html|title=''Orange Is the New Black'' Episode Eight Recap: Your Fault, Your Mess|last=Henderson|first=Danielle|date=August 13, 2013|work=Vulture|accessdate=August 31, 2015}} In the final episode of the season, Nichols is seen to be seducing [[Alex Vause]] (played by [[Laura Prepon]]), who is a love interest of Chapman.{{cite news|url=http://www.afterellen.com/tv/191973-orange-is-the-new-black-recap-1-13-cant-fix-crazy/3|title=''Orange Is the New Black'' recap (1.13): Can’t Fix Crazy|last=Davis|first=Ali|date=July 25, 2013|work=After Ellen|accessdate=August 31, 2015}} ===Season 2=== Nichols engages in a competition with Carrie "Big Boo" Black (played by [[Lea DeLaria]]) to see who can have sex with the most women in the prison.{{cite news|url=http://www.express.co.uk/life-style/life/502281/Big-Boo-Lea-DeLaria-Orange-Is-The-New-Black-interview|title='Playing Big Boo is my dream come true,' says ''Orange Is The New Black''′s Lea DeLaria|last=Barns|first=Sarah|work=[[Daily Express]]|accessdate=August 31, 2015}} Nichols spends a long time trying to seduce one of the correctional officers. She is not successful.{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/style-blog/wp/2014/06/06/orange-is-the-new-black-season-2-recap-halfway-through-already-lets-discuss/|title=''Orange Is the New Black'' Season 2 recap: Halfway through already? Let’s discuss.|date=June 6, 2014|last=Yahr|first=Emily|work=[[The Washington Post]]|accessdate=August 31, 2015}} Eventually, they both call it a draw at 36 points and engage in a 'cookie-eating contest' instead.{{cite news|url=http://www.afterellen.com/tv/219970-orange-is-the-new-black-recap-2-6-you-also-have-a-pizza/5|title=''Orange Is the New Black'' recap (2.6): You Also Have a Pizza|date=June 23, 2014|last=Piccoli|first=Dana|work=After Ellen|accessdate=August 31, 2015}} The other major storyline for Nichols in this season involves heroin that she accepts from another inmate.{{cite news|url=http://www.avclub.com/tvclub/orange-new-black-40-oz-furloughlittle-mustachioed--205646|title=''Orange Is The New Black'': “40 OZ Of Furlough”/“Little Mustachioed Shit”|date=July 1, 2014|last=McNutt|first=Myles|work=[[The A.V. Club]]|accessdate=August 31, 2015}} ===Season 3=== Nichols and Big Boo, attempt to sell their stash of heroin and they cooperate with correctional officer Joel Luschek, who finds a buyer.{{cite news|url=http://www.pastemagazine.com/articles/2015/06/orange-is-the-new-black-review-mothers-daybed-bugs.html|title=''Orange Is the New Black'' Review: “Mother’s Day”/“Bed Bugs and Beyond”|date=June 14, 2015|last=Amatangelo|first=Amy|work=[[Paste (magazine)|Paste]]|accessdate=August 31, 2015}} Nichols then says that it has been stolen but, in reality, she has hidden it for her own use. Other inmates Leanne Taylor (played by [[Emma Myles]]) and Angie Rice (played by [[Julie Lake]]) find the heroin and start taking it. Luschek discovers this and confiscates the drug.{{cite news|url=http://www.ew.com/recap/orange-is-the-new-black-season-3-episode-3|title=Empathy Is a Boner Killer|date=June 11, 2015|last=Dornbush|first=Jonathon|work=Entertainment Weekly|accessdate=August 31, 2015}} When assistant warden [[List_of_Orange_Is_the_New_Black_characters#Joseph_Salvatore_.22Joe.22_Caputo|Joe Caputo]] (played by [[Nick Sandow]]) discovers the heroin, Luschek blames Nichols and Nichols is sent to a maximum security prison.{{cite news|url=http://www.pastemagazine.com/articles/2015/06/orange-is-the-new-black-review-empathy-is-a-boner.html|title=''Orange Is the New Black'' Review: “Empathy is a Boner Killer”/“Finger in the Dyke”|date=June 15, 2015|last=Amatangelo|first=Amy|work=Paste|accessdate=August 31, 2015}} This is Nichols's last appearance in the third season. ===Season 4=== In the midst of season four, Nichols can be seen in an episode as a maximum security inmate, along with Sophia Burset and Stella Carlin. Luschek repents of his actions against Nichols, and asks new inmate Judy King to use her connections to get Nichols out of maximum security. She returns to minimum security where she is welcomed with a big party. Her drug problem persists, however. ===Season 5=== During a prison riot, Nichols decides to take over the pharmacy with Lorna Morello. Later, while Soso is depressed and asking Nichols for drugs, Nichols confess that she has hopelessly fallen in love with "an incredible, insane, beautiful woman" who would never love her back. Morello overhears everything but does not comment. In a later episode, Nichols and Morello restart their sexual relationship, but Morello ends it a few hours after, saying that during their intercourse she realized she was pregnant. Nichols does not believe her and is heartbroken. Vause finds her crying in the shower. While Red is becoming paranoid because of the correctional officer (CO) Piscatella, Nichols decides to take care of her but is eventually abducted by the CO. She is kept in a room tied up with the rest of her prison "family". After they are able to escape, Nichols goes back to the pharmacy to see Morello and realizes that she is actually pregnant. She then calls Morello's husband to convince him to stay with her because "some people would give anything to be loved like that". While the police begins to raid the prison, she asks Morello to surrender and tell them that she is pregnant. Nichols then returns to Frieda's bunker and they all wait for the police to enter. ==Critical commentary== Sarah Karlan of ''[[BuzzFeed]]'' praised the character's "impossibly quick wit" and "perfectly deadpan delivery".{{cite news|url=https://www.buzzfeed.com/skarlan/for-anyone-slowly-falling-for-nicky-nichols-on-orange-is-the#.phv3A92vq|title=For Anyone Slowly Falling For Nicky Nichols On ''Orange Is The New Black''|last=Karlan|first=Sarah|date=June 12, 2014|work=BuzzFeed|accessdate=August 30, 2015}} Rebekah Allen of ''[[SheWired]]'' said Lyonne is "wonderful" in the role, and called Nichols one of the best characters on the series.{{cite news|url=http://www.shewired.com/television/2015/07/29/natasha-lyonne-opens-about-dreadful-nicky-nichols-development-orange-new-black|title=Natasha Lyonne Opens Up About that Dreadful Nicky Nichols Development in ''OITNB'' Season 3|last=Allen|first=Rebekah|date=July 29, 2015|work=[[SheWired]]|accessdate=August 30, 2015}} [[MTV]]'s Crystal Bell called Nichols a "fan-favorite" and "our beloved smart mouth" and expressed disappointment at the character's departure in the third season.{{cite news|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/2186915/orange-is-the-new-black-nicky/|title=Did ''Orange Is The New Black'' Really Say Goodbye To This Fan-Favorite Character For Good?|last=Bell|first=Crystal|date=June 15, 2015|publisher=[[MTV]]|accessdate=August 30, 2015}} Lyonne received an [[Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Guest Actress in a Comedy Series|Emmy nomination]] for her role as Nichols. She lost out to fellow ''Orange Is the New Black'' actress [[Uzo Aduba]].{{cite news|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2014/08/25/showbiz/primetime-emmy-awards-winners-2014/|title=Primetime Emmy Awards 2014: The winners list|date=August 26, 2014|publisher=[[CNN]]|accessdate=August 30, 2015}} ==See also== *[[List of Orange Is the New Black characters|List of ''Orange Is the New Black'' characters]] ==References== {{reflist|33em}} {{Orange Is the New Black}} [[Category:Female characters in television]] [[Category:Fictional American Jews]] [[Category:Fictional characters from New York City]] [[Category:Fictional characters introduced in 2013]] [[Category:Fictional criminals]] [[Category:Fictional drug addicts]] [[Category:Fictional lesbians]] [[Category:Fictional LGBT characters in television]] [[Category:Orange Is the New Black characters]]

{{distinguish|text=the former Tunisian prime minister [[Mohamed Ghannouchi]]}} {{Infobox person | name = Rached Ghannouchi
{{lang|ar|راشد الغنوشي}} | image = {{CSS image crop |Image = Rached Ghannouchi 3.jpg |bSize = 360 |cWidth = 270 |cHeight = 270 |oTop = 50 |oLeft = 40 |Location = centre |Description = |100px }} | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1941|6|7|df=y}} | birth_place = [[El Hamma]], [[French protectorate of Tunisia|Tunisia]] | death_date = | death_place = | alma_mater = [[Cairo University]]
[[Damascus University]] | party = [[Ennahda Movement]] | father = Sheikh Muhammad | website = {{URL|http://www.rachedelghannouchi.com}} | religion = }} '''Rached Ghannouchi''' ({{lang-ar|راشد الغنوشي}} ''{{transl|ar|Rāshid al-Ghannūshī}}''; born 7 June 1941), also spelled '''Rachid al-Ghannouchi''' or '''Rached el-Ghannouchi''', is a [[Tunisia]]n politician and thinker, co-founder of the [[Ennahdha Party]] and serving as its "intellectual leader".{{cite news |last=Feldman |first=Noah |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-10-30/islamists-victory-in-tunisia-a-win-for-democracy-noah-feldman.html |title=Islamists' Victory in Tunisia a Win for Democracy: Noah Feldman |publisher=Bloomberg |date=2011-10-30 |accessdate=2011-10-31}} He was born '''Rashad Khriji''' ({{lang|ar|راشد الخريجي}}).{{cite web |last=Turess Press |title=إلى الأستاذ راشد الخريجي (حركة النهضة) |url=http://www.turess.com/alchourouk/194456 |accessdate=16 June 2013}} Ghannouchi was named one of [[Time (magazine)|''Time'']]'s [[Time 100|100 Most Influential People in the World]] in 2012{{cite news |title=TIME 100: The List |url=http://www.time.com/time/specials/packages/article/0,28804,2111975_2111976_2112133,00.html |work=Time |accessdate=14 February 2013 |date=18 April 2012}} and [[Foreign Policy (magazine)|''Foreign Policy'']]'s [[FP Top 100 Global Thinkers|Top 100 Global Thinkers]]{{cite web |last=Foreign Policy |title=The FP Top 100 Global Thinkers 2011 |url=https://foreignpolicy.com/articles/2011/11/28/the_fp_top_100_global_thinkers}} and was awarded the [[Chatham House Prize]] in 2012 (alongside Tunisian President [[Moncef Marzouki]]) by [[Prince Andrew, Duke of York]], for "the successful compromises each achieved during Tunisia's democratic transition".{{cite web |last=Chatham House |title=Chatham House Prize 2012 |url=http://www.chathamhouse.org/chatham-house-prize/2012}}{{cite web |last=Ghannouchi |first=Rached |title=Transcript of speech at Chatham House Prize 2012 awards ceremony, 26 November 2012 |url=http://www.chathamhouse.org/sites/files/chathamhouse/public/Meetings/Meeting%20Transcripts/261112CHPrize.pdf}} In 2016 he received the [[Jamnalal Bajaj Award]] for "promoting [[Gandhian]] values outside [[India]]".{{Cite web|url=http://www.jamnalalbajajawards.org/awards/archives/2016/international/rached-ghannouchi|title=Jamnalal Bajaj Awards|publisher=Jamnalal Bajaj Foundation|access-date=2017-02-16}} ==Early life== Ghannouchi was born outside [[El Hamma]], in the [[Gabès Governorate|governorate of Gabès]] in southern Tunisia. His village had no electricity or paved roads. His father was a poor farmer with children including Rached. His family worked in the fields every day, and had meat to eat only a few times a year.{{cite book |last1=Worth |first1=Robert F. |title=A Rage for Order: The Middle East in Turmoil, from Tahrir Square to ISIS |date=2016 |publisher=Pan Macmillan |pages=203–4 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=PNOLCgAAQBAJ&pg=PP7&dq=rage+for+order+worth&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjO4L2trp7OAhWo5IMKHRzTD0cQ6AEILDAD#v=onepage&q=rage%20for%20order%20worth&f=false |accessdate=31 July 2016 |ref=RFWRfO2016}} After the ground season had ended, the family wove baskets from palm leaves to supplement its income. Rached was able to attend a local branch of the traditional Arabic-language Zaytouna school thanks to financial help from an older brother. He received his certificate of attainment degree, equivalent to the [[Baccalauréat]], in 1962 from the [[University of Ez-Zitouna]] (Zaytouna). He entered the school of [[agriculture]] at [[Cairo University]] in 1964 but, following the expulsion of Tunisians from [[Egypt]], he left for [[Syria]]. He studied [[philosophy]] at the [[University of Damascus]], graduating in 1968. Ghannouchi also spent some time in his 20s traveling and working in Europe as a grape picker and dish washer. ==Islamic Tendency Movement== In April 1981 Ghannouchi founded the Islamic Tendency Movement ({{lang-ar|حركة الاتجاه الإسلامي}} ''{{transl|ar|Ḥarakat al-Ittijāh al-Islāmī}}''). The Movement described itself as specifically rooted in [[Nonviolence|non-violent]] [[Islamism]], and called for a "reconstruction of economic life on a more equitable basis, the end of single-party politics and the acceptance of political pluralism and democracy."{{cite news |last1=Kechichian |first1=Joseph A. |title=A genuine Islamist democrat |url=http://gulfnews.com/culture/people/a-genuine-islamist-democrat-1.865958 |accessdate=18 October 2016 |agency=Gulf News |date=September 16, 2011}} By the end of July, Ghannouchi and his followers were arrested, sentenced to eleven years in prison in [[Bizerte]], and were tortured. Both the religious and secular community, including numerous secular political organizations, rallied in his support.Linda G. Jones, "Portrait of Rashid Al-Ghannoushi" ''Middle East Report'', No. 153 (July–August 1988). While in prison he translated a number of works and wrote on topics such as democracy, women's rights, and Palestine. He also wrote his most noted work, ''Al‐Hurriyat al‐'Ammah'' (Public Liberties).{{cite web |title=Rachid Ghannouchi: A Democrat Within Islamism. The Question of Democracy, Azzam S. Tamimi |url=http://www.oxfordscholarship.com/view/10.1093/0195140001.001.0001/acprof-9780195140002-chapter-3 |website=Oxford Scholarship Online |accessdate=18 October 2016}} He was released in 1984, but returned to prison in 1987 with a life sentence, then was again released in 1988. He moved to the [[United Kingdom]] as a political exile, where he lived for 22 years.{{Cite news|url=http://www.thetimes.co.uk/tto/news/world/middleeast/article3200426.ece|title=The exile close to winning first Arab Spring election {{!}} The Times|work=The Times|access-date=2017-03-08|language=en-GB}} He attended The Islamic Committee for Palestine conference in Chicago in 1989.{{cite news |title=Islamic Jihad Movement in Palestine |url=http://www.kintera.org/atf/cf/%7B42D75369-D582-4380-8395-D25925B85EAF%7D/IslamicJihadMovement_July2002.pdf}} Following the 1990 invasion of Kuwait, Al-Ghannushi denounced King Fahd of Saudi Arabia for the "colossal crime" of inviting the U.S. to deploy forces.{{cite news |title=A U.S. Visa for Rachid Ghannouchi? |url=http://www.martinkramer.org/sandbox/reader/archives/a-u-s-visa-for-rachid-ghannouchi/}} He also called for a Muslim boycott of American goods, planes and ships. He has also been criticized for calling for jihad against Israel.{{cite web |last1=Merley |first1=Steven |title=Tunisian Muslim Brotherhood Leader Speaks In Washington; Rachid Ghannouchi Has Long History Of Extremism And Support For Terrorism |url=http://www.globalmbwatch.com/2014/10/13/tunisian-muslim-brotherhood-leader-speaks-washington-rachid-ghannouchi-long-history-extremism-support-terrorism/ |website=Global Muslim Brotherhood Daily Watch |accessdate=18 October 2016 |date=October 13, 2014}}{{cite web |title=Rachid Ghannouchi |url=http://www.globalmbwatch.com/rachid-ghannouchi/ |website=Global Muslim Brotherhood Daily Watch |accessdate=18 October 2016}}{{cite web |title=Rachid Ghannouchi: A Democrat Within Islamism. Ghannouchi's Detractors, Azzam S. Tamimi [summary] |url=http://www.oxfordscholarship.com/view/10.1093/0195140001.001.0001/acprof-9780195140002-chapter-8 |website=Oxford Scholarship Online |accessdate=18 October 2016}} [[File:RachedGhannouchi.jpg|thumb|180px|Rachid Al-Ghannouchi speaking in an Islamist rally circa 1980.]] Ghannouchi continued to criticise [[Politics of Tunisia|Tunisian politics]] and the regime of President [[Zine El Abidine Ben Ali]].{{cite news |title=More Officials Quit in Tunisia Amid Protests |first1=David D. |last1=Kirkpatrick |first2=Kareem |last2=Fahim |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/01/19/world/africa/19tunis.html?_r=1&scp=1&sq=More%20officials%20quit%20in%20tunisia&st=cse |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |date=18 January 2011 |accessdate=19 January 2011}} ==Tunisian Revolution and after== Following [[2010–2011 Tunisian uprising|popular unrest]] in which Ben Ali was ousted, Ghannouchi returned to Tunisia on 30 January 2011, after spending twenty two years exiled in [[London]],{{cite news |url=http://aawsat.com/details.asp?section=4&issueno=11751&article=606016&feature= |script-title=ar:راشد الغنوشي زعيم حركة النهضة يعود إلى تونس اليوم بعد 20 عاما في المنفى |publisher=[[Asharq Al-Awsat]] |date=30 January 2011 |language=ar}} with thousands{{cite news |title=Rached Ghannouchi de retour à Tunis après 20 ans d'exil : un accueil exceptionnel |url=http://www.leaders.com.tn/article/3880-rached-ghannouchi-de-retour-a-tunis-apres-20-ans-d-exil-un-accueil-exceptionnel |accessdate=30 January 2011 |newspaper=Leaders |date=30 January 2011}} of people welcoming him. His party won 37.04% of the vote (more than the next four biggest vote-getting parties combined){{cite journal |last=Gerges |first=Fawaz |title=The Many Voices of Political Islam |journal=The Majalla |date=June 2012 |volume=1573 |pages=14–18 |url=http://www.majalla.com/eng/print-edition-pdf/al-majalla-issue-1573.pdf |accessdate=4 April 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130730045231/http://www.majalla.com/eng/print-edition-pdf/al-majalla-issue-1573.pdf |archivedate=30 July 2013 |df= }} in the 2011 [[Tunisian Constituent Assembly election, 2011|Tunisian Constituent Assembly election]]. Ghannouchi did not take a government position. Ennahdha's secretary-general [[Hamadi Jebali]] became [[Prime Minister of Tunisia|Prime Minister]].{{cite web |first=Houda |last=Mzioudet |title=Ennahdha's Jebali Appointed as Tunisian Prime Minister |newspaper=Tunisia Live |date=14 December 2011 |url=http://www.tunisia-live.net/2011/12/14/ennahdas-jebali-appointed-as-tunisian-prime-minister/ |accessdate=21 December 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120117044127/http://www.tunisia-live.net/2011/12/14/ennahdas-jebali-appointed-as-tunisian-prime-minister/ |archivedate=17 January 2012 |df= }} Ennahda formed a government which led Tunisia through the challenging and tumultuous aftermath of the [[Tunisian revolution|Jasmine revolution]]. The government during this period was characterized by greater transparency, lack of corruption, and consensus-building. In March 2012, Ennahda declared it would not support making sharia the main source of legislation in the new constitution, maintaining the secular nature of the state. Ennahda's stance on the issue was criticized by hardline Islamists, who wanted strict sharia, but was welcomed by secular parties.{{cite web|title=Tunisia's constitution will not be based on Sharia: Islamist party|url=http://www.alarabiya.net/articles/2012/03/27/203529.html|publisher=Al Arabiya|accessdate=18 February 2013}} The government was criticized for mediocre economic performance, not stimulating the tourism industry, and poor relations with Tunisia's biggest trading partner France. In particular it was criticized for tolerating efforts at aggressive Islamisation by radical Islamists who were demanding Sharia law and denouncing gender inequality and restrictions on polygamy,{{cite book |title=Islamism: What it Means for the Middle East and the World |last1=Osman |first1=Tarek |publisher=Yale University Press |year=2016 |accessdate=16 October 2016 |page=85 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=vKZ5CwAAQBAJ&printsec=frontcover&dq=islamism+tarek+osman&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiC5OWDiOLPAhXKdj4KHXsMBp0Q6AEIHDAA#v=onepage&q=burgeoning%20&f=false}} some of whom were responsible for the September 2012 ransacking and burning of the American embassy and school following the online publication of the trailer for a controversial anti-Islamic film, and the assassination of two leftist politicians [[Chokri Belaid]] (in February 2013) and [[Mohamed Brahmi]] (in July 2013). During this [[2013–14 Tunisian political crisis]] enraged secularists demanded the government step down or even a Sisi-style coup, while Ennahda militants defiantly opposed early elections, even booing Ghannouchi's calls for sacrifice for national unity.{{cite book |last1=Worth |first1=Robert F. |title=A Rage for Order: The Middle East in Turmoil, from Tahrir Square to ISIS |date=2016 |publisher=Pan Macmillan |pages=199–204 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=PNOLCgAAQBAJ&pg=PP7&dq=rage+for+order+worth&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjO4L2trp7OAhWo5IMKHRzTD0cQ6AEILDAD#v=onepage&q=rage%20for%20order%20worth&f=false |accessdate=31 July 2016 |ref=RFWRfO2016}} Nonetheless Ghanouchi worked with secularist leader [[Beji Caid Essebsi]] to forge a compromise and on October 5 signed a "road map" whereby Ennahda would step down for a caretaker government after the new constitution was agreed upon and until new elections were held.{{cite book |last1=Worth |first1=Robert F. |title=A Rage for Order: The Middle East in Turmoil, from Tahrir Square to ISIS |date=2016 |publisher=Pan Macmillan |page=206 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=PNOLCgAAQBAJ&pg=PP7&dq=rage+for+order+worth&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjO4L2trp7OAhWo5IMKHRzTD0cQ6AEILDAD#v=onepage&q=rage%20for%20order%20worth&f=false |accessdate=31 July 2016 |ref=RFWRfO2016}} Both leaders were heavily criticized by their party rank and file and Ghannouchi received agreement from the Ennahda shura council only by threatening to resign.{{cite book |last1=Worth |first1=Robert F. |title=A Rage for Order: The Middle East in Turmoil, from Tahrir Square to ISIS |date=2016 |publisher=Pan Macmillan |pages=205, 207 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=PNOLCgAAQBAJ&pg=PP7&dq=rage+for+order+worth&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjO4L2trp7OAhWo5IMKHRzTD0cQ6AEILDAD#v=onepage&q=rage%20for%20order%20worth&f=false |accessdate=31 July 2016 |ref=RFWRfO2016}} In January 2014, after the new Tunisian Constitution was approved, Ennahdha peacefully quit government and handed power to a technocratic government led by [[Mehdi Jomaa]]. Ennahda placed second in the [[Tunisian parliamentary election, 2014|October 2014 parliamentary election]] with 27.79% of the popular vote and formed a coalition government with the larger secularist party [[Nidaa Tounes]] despite rank-and-file opposition. Ennahda did not put forth a presidential candidate for the November 2014 election.{{Cite news |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2014/09/07/us-tunisia-election-ennahda-idUSKBN0H20LJ20140907 |title=Tunisia's main Islamist party to stay out of presidential election |publisher=Reuters |date=8 September 2014 |accessdate=20 September 2014}} Ghanouchi "hinted broadly" that he personally supported Beji Caid Essebsi{{cite book |last1=Worth |first1=Robert F. |title=A Rage for Order: The Middle East in Turmoil, from Tahrir Square to ISIS |date=2016 |publisher=Pan Macmillan |pages=219 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=PNOLCgAAQBAJ&pg=PP7&dq=rage+for+order+worth&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjO4L2trp7OAhWo5IMKHRzTD0cQ6AEILDAD#v=onepage&q=rage%20for%20order%20worth&f=false |accessdate=31 July 2016 |ref=RFWRfO2016}} (who won with over 55% of the vote). Ghannouchi argued for these accommodating measures against more purist party members on the grounds that the country was still too fragile, and the economy too much in need of reform, for Ennahda to be in opposition.{{cite book |last1=Worth |first1=Robert F. |title=A Rage for Order: The Middle East in Turmoil, from Tahrir Square to ISIS |date=2016 |publisher=Pan Macmillan |pages=218 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=PNOLCgAAQBAJ&pg=PP7&dq=rage+for+order+worth&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjO4L2trp7OAhWo5IMKHRzTD0cQ6AEILDAD#v=onepage&q=rage%20for%20order%20worth&f=false |accessdate=31 July 2016 |ref=RFWRfO2016}} Ghannouchi also gave his support to a crackdown on jihadi indoctrination at radical mosques (over 60 civilians, mostly tourists, were [[List of terrorist incidents in Tunisia|killed]] in 2015 by jihadis, devastating Tunisia's tourist industry). Despite his Islamist background, he had always been "reviled" by jihadis, according to Robert Worth, and now appeared near "the top" of the jihadi "wanted list".{{cite book |last1=Worth |first1=Robert F. |title=A Rage for Order: The Middle East in Turmoil, from Tahrir Square to ISIS |date=2016 |publisher=Pan Macmillan |pages=220 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=PNOLCgAAQBAJ&pg=PP7&dq=rage+for+order+worth&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjO4L2trp7OAhWo5IMKHRzTD0cQ6AEILDAD#v=onepage&q=rage%20for%20order%20worth&f=false |accessdate=31 July 2016 |ref=RFWRfO2016}} ===BBC apology in 2013=== On 17 May 2013, the [[BBC]] published an apology on their website for previously publishing inaccurate statements about Ghannouchi six months earlier on 21 November 2012.{{cite news |title=Apology to Rached Ghannouchi |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-22464773 |accessdate=27 May 2013 |newspaper=BBC.co.uk |date=17 May 2013}} The article had accused Ghannouchi of threatening to order troops on to the streets if the Ennahdha Party did not get the results he expected in the elections in 2011, and suggested he condoned the violent Salafist attack on the United States embassy and the burning of the [[American School in Tunis]] in September 2012. Acknowledging that none of these accusations and suggestions were in fact true, the retraction concluded: "The BBC apologises to Mr Ghannouchi for these mistakes and for the distress they caused him." ===The Independent apology in 2012=== On 9 October 2012, [[The Independent]] published an apology on their website for suggesting, in a previous article, that the party Ghannouchi leads, Ennahdha (An Nahda) has been offered foreign funds. The apology stated: "we wish to make it clear that Mr Ghannouchi and his party have not accepted any donation from a foreign state in breach of Tunisian party funding laws. We apologise to Mr Ghannouchi."{{Cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/corrections/rachid-ghannouchi-8203500.html|title=Rachid Ghannouchi|work=The Independent|access-date=2018-11-17|language=en-GB}} ===The Economist apology in 2011=== On 22 October 2011, [[The Economist]] published an apology on their website for previously publishing an article in which they attributed false statements to Ghannouchi. The article{{Cite news|url=https://www.economist.com/briefing/2011/10/15/now-is-the-time|title=Now is the time|work=The Economist|access-date=2018-11-17|language=en}} claimed that Ghannouchi "opposes the country's liberal code of individual rights, the Code of Personal Status, and its prohibition of polygamy". The article, also, claimed that Ghannouchi "has threatened to hang a prominent Tunisian feminist, Raja bin Salama, in Basij Square in Tunis, because she has called for the country's new laws to be based on the Universal Declaration of Human Rights". The apology{{Cite news|url=https://www.economist.com/middle-east-and-africa/2011/10/22/an-apology-to-rachid-ghannouchi|title=An apology to Rachid Ghannouchi|work=The Economist|access-date=2018-11-17|language=en}} stated that "we accept that neither of these statements is true: Mr Ghannouchi has expressly said that he accepts the Code of Personal Status; and he never threatened to hang Ms bin Salama. We apologise to him unreservedly." ==Views and background== Ghannouchi's willingness to compromise with secularists in Tunisia and his country's unique success in maintaining a democratic system following the Arab Spring has been credited by at least one observer ([[Robert F. Worth|Robert Worth]]) to his background. Unlike many Islamists, Ghannouchi "lived abroad for decades, reading widely in three languages", including Western thinkers [[Karl Marx]], [[Sigmund Freud]] and [[Jean-Paul Sartre]]. He admired the courage of leftists who protested in the streets against the dictatorship, were arrested and tortured in prison, and became willing to work with them.{{cite book |last1=Worth |first1=Robert F. |title=A Rage for Order: The Middle East in Turmoil, from Tahrir Square to ISIS |date=2016 |publisher=Pan Macmillan |pages=207–8 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=PNOLCgAAQBAJ&pg=PP7&dq=rage+for+order+worth&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjO4L2trp7OAhWo5IMKHRzTD0cQ6AEILDAD#v=onepage&q=rage%20for%20order%20worth&f=false |accessdate=31 July 2016 |ref=RFWRfO2016}} Watching the [[Islamic Salvation Front#General strike and arrests of leadership|initial victory of the Algerian Islamists]]—while exiled in London—collapse into the slaughter, mayhem and defeat of the [[Algerian Civil War|civil war]], left a deep impact.{{cite book |last1=Worth |first1=Robert F. |title=A Rage for Order: The Middle East in Turmoil, from Tahrir Square to ISIS |date=2016 |publisher=Pan Macmillan |pages=209 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=PNOLCgAAQBAJ&pg=PP7&dq=rage+for+order+worth&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjO4L2trp7OAhWo5IMKHRzTD0cQ6AEILDAD#v=onepage&q=rage%20for%20order%20worth&f=false |accessdate=31 July 2016 |ref=RFWRfO2016}} According to Azzam S. Tamimi, he was influenced by [[Malek Bennabi|Malik Bennabi]] and his treatise "Islam and Democracy", which laid "the foundations" for Ghannouchi's "masterpiece" ''Al‐Hurriyat al‐'Ammah'' (''Public Liberties''). In 2002, an unsympathetic Western source ([[Martin Kramer]]) described him as differing "from other Islamists" in his insistence "that Islam accepts multi-party democracy."{{cite journal |last1=Kramer |first1=Martin |title=Rachid Ghannouchi: A Democrat within Islamism |url=http://www.meforum.org/1492/rachid-ghannouchi-a-democrat-within-islamism |accessdate=18 October 2016 |volume=1 |issue=4 |journal=Middle East Quarterly |date=Fall 2002}} In 2015, he told French journalist Olivier Ravanello that homosexuality should not be criminalized, though he opposed gay marriage.{{cite news |last1=Guizani |first1=Emna |title=News Rached Ghannouchi: Homosexuality Should Not Be Criminalized |url=http://www.tunisia-live.net/2015/04/20/rached-ghannouchi-homosexuality-should-not-be-criminalized/ |accessdate=17 October 2016 |agency=tunisia-live.net |date=April 20, 2015}} He has been
